Hi all,

I've been looking at the jneat code, specifically
Genome.mutate_ad=
d_node, to try to understand how innovations work in
this case. 

If the co=
nnection to add a new node to is A->B, we look through the
list of innovati=
ons to see if there's already been a new node
innovation for A->B, provided=
 the innovation for A->B itself is the
same as well.

If there's no matchin=
g innovation, then we can create a new node C,
connection A->C->B, and crea=
te a new node innovation.

However, if there is a matching innovation, then=
 create a node with
the node ID from the innovation (call it C), and connec=
t A->C->B.

The issue that I see is that A->B still exists (whether enabled=
 or
disabled). So if, in the same network that now contains A->C->B, the
al=
gorithm happens to choose A->B for a new node again, it is
guaranteed to fi=
nd the innovation with new node C... and thus we would
get two nodes with t=
he same ID.

Is this the intended behavior, or am I reading this wrong?

Th=
anks,

--Rob
